Description: Attic red-figured pottery mug, reconstructed from fragments. Two long-haired athletes facing each other as they bend forward, one holding a discus, the other a pair of halteres (jumping weights); a sponge hangs in the field. Under the handle a flower consisting of two tendrils, one ending in a spiral, the other in a heart-shaped leaf; on the top of the handle a reserved triangle. Much plaster restoration, particularly on the bottom and handle (which should be broader).
Producer name: Attributed to: The Painter of Berlin 2268
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
On this mug and its shape, see J. R. Green, 'Oinochoe', Bulletin of the Institute of Classical Studies 19 (1972), 1-16, pl. 2a.
Bibliographic references: CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 114 no. 4-5, pl. 62, no. 4-5)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1767)
